segments.text: I've always felt that the military was one way you could pay some rent on the space you occupied in this country.
In other words, patriotism.
Call it what you want.
And I don't know how much of it's hereditary, how much of it's A&M.
I've always been a fairly conscientious soldier.
During 1961, when we were down in Fort Polk, or early 1962, and we were on maneuvers, Iron Dragon, and I was Combat Command, Sea Command.
General West called me up one night.
I know he was under pressure.
He told me, I want you to send
One outfit that way and one outfit that way.
Do you understand?
I said, yes, sir.
So at the break, I went up to General West, and I said, General, I'd like to talk to you privately.
And he said, what's it about?
I said, would you step outside the tent where we could talk privately?
I said, General, I like my job, and I know there's no profit in this conversation.
But did you realize the two of us were trying to run the same outfit?
I said, if you just tell me what you want done, I'll work my butt off to get it done.
And if I don't, you can have my head.
But will you let me run my own outfit?
But I used to tell my battalions down there,
If my staff comes in there and tries to run your outfit and you don't kick them out, then I'm going to look at you.
Because I'm paying you, or the government is, to run your outfit.
And if I find you can't, I'll get somebody else.
That's the way I feel.
I also feel that there's no one guy that's so important we can't get along with that.
That's about my story.
What did you decide to go in the Texas National Guard instead of the Army Reserves?
Well, I was already in the Army Reserves when I got out.
I signed up for it.
See, the Texas National Guard or any National Guard, you have a dual commission.
Reserve Washington, federally recognized guard, too.
I got in that by the back door.
Travis Bryan, Sr., who I've been friends with for a long, long time.
He had many, many friends in the military.
He called me one day and he said, come on down to the bank.
I want to talk to you.
Was this in 1947?
He had a Colonel Fitzhugh, who was senior advisor
And I said, we were forming probably late 46.
I said, we're forming the 49th Army Division.
The division headquartered the engineer battalion.
Brian would like you to take it over.
I said, all right.
So they hadn't formed the headquarters, so they couldn't have a battalion commander.
They had formed the headquarters company.
So I took federal recognition as a captain and a motor officer.
Is that why you went, you skipped down to a captain, you were a major, you went down to a captain, then you went back up to a lieutenant colonel, and you skipped the major?
Will you explain how you kept skipping around in the ranks for a couple of months?
Well, the reason why was they hadn't formed the headquarters.
You see, each unit has what we call a table of organizational equipment, you see.
for one lieutenant colonel, one major, two majors, so on.
And they didn't have a headquarters, so they didn't have a spot for a lieutenant colonel.
They had a headquarters company, you see.
So I took a job as captain motor officer, just to go on and get here.
And got federally recognized captaincy.
And the minute they formed the headquarters, then I got federally recognized lieutenant colonel.
And I commanded the unit for 11 years.
And I finally went to CG, and I said, General, I've been commanding this unit for 11 years.
All I'm doing now is going over the same old things again and again.
And I said, I'm holding up everybody else in my outfit.
He said, have you got a job on the staff?
He said, maybe.
So I became a trains commander.
Now, what did you do with the 386th armored engineering battalion?
What did I do with it?
Tell me about the signs.
What was your task?
Well, we had the headquarters company, bridge company, three lines.
So you had a total personnel of what?
Between 800 and 1,000.
And what I did with it, I feel like I made one of the best battalions in the 49th Army.
So you did a lot of training?
Yes, sir.
We did a lot of training.
We did a lot of planning.
C.B.
Hewitt, Cap Hewitt was my exec.
And we'd have planning sessions, what if we got people out of the railroad center, you know, which I'd been through.
How would we handle that situation?
What if this, what if that?
And try to do those things.
And, of course, we had to go through whatever training cycles were prescribed by the military.
But we just tried to be the people that did our job.
Did Korea have any impact on your job?
No, it didn't, except it had an impact on my business.
The number one latrine room was flying fast and thick, and I could not see going back active duty for the business.
And it prompted me to sell out to my partner, who later went broke.
In other words, you thought then that you would be called up during the Korean War?
Yes, sir.
In fact, the rumors were real strife.
And later on, I talked to Johnny Johnson, and he said, I just finally went to Washington.
And he said, I was flat-ass.
And they said, General, we were fixing to call one more division, specifically the 49th Armored Division.
when we decided not to call it a morning.
So that's how close to 50 we came to it.
How are your feelings?
Did you want to go to a funeral?
Not particularly, but like I said, they tell me where to go, I go.
It's about that simple.
Did your training techniques change in any way because of the war?
Did you train more intensively?
Did you meet more often?
No.
For a long time, we met on Monday nights.
One thing we were certainly aware of was what our strengths and what our limitations were.
We must necessarily have some limitations.
Then they went to what they called
which instead of meeting Monday night, four nights a month or five nights, we had a drill on Saturday and Sunday, and you got credit for four drills.
You got paid on basically four drills where you could get more done.
So you could get more done on the weekend.
Right.
How about morale?
Did it have any impact on morale?
I don't think so.
It had either way.
You see, we had two types of people.
One of them was former people during the war.
The others were those who perhaps took that in lieu of being drafted.
Was there any conflict between these two different types?
It was in every organization.
We had Goodwin's and we had Sargent's.
But I had my niece's husband who lived in his private and rose off fast and got to start approaching Sargent.
In fact, he was recommended for it.
So we sat back and looked, and we devised
a test and decreed that in our battalion that nobody got to be promoted above a corporal without passing the test.
And we instituted various stations.
We'd set them up.
Said, we're not telling you, company commander, who you can promote or not promote.
All we can tell you is if he doesn't pass it, we won't accept him.
And we'd set up first aid stations
We wanted to know first aid and sanitation.
We wanted to know how to field strip an M1 rifle, machine gun, things that basically, if you were a specialist, such as a demolition specialist, we want to know
what the safety procedures were, how to wire parallel and series, and what the effects were, all of those things.
So your mission was training?
Sir?
Your mission was training?
Yes, sir.
And preparation?
Yes, sir.
And we knew what our limitations were and what our strengths were.
That's exactly what it was.
Okay, after 11 years of this stuff,
You moved down to the 49th Army Division?
Division trains.
You stayed there for three years, and what was your mission now?
Again, training.
I don't know if you're familiar with trains, but that's your support units, your ordnance battalion, your quartermaster battalion, all of those, and the band.
I set standards.
It was like I went to Quartermaster Battalion at one time.
And they were good out there.
You were activated in 1961 during the Berlin crisis, and you were activated for, let's say, about ten months, from 61 to August of 62.
Why were you activated?
The whole division was activated.
The entire division was activated?
The president has that right.
And so, where'd you go?
We went to Louisiana.
See, in June, I had to come back and come in secretly.
We went to Louisiana.
Was there a lot of war going on?
No, not particularly.
It was a Berlin crisis.
It could have developed into something.
But our mission was to get ready and be effective.
And we made it.
General West, our division commander at the time, was one of the few people who could carry us through and face the difficulties.
Everything there, even support groups were reserved, Baton Rouge and so forth and there.
And we were put under considerable intolerable situations with really lack of funding.
He had to do a lot of deficit funding.
And I really think the feel that the Army expected us to make, maybe a full-time professional soldier feels a part-time professional soldier can't do it.
In other words, was there a conflict, an antagonism between the regulars and the reserves?
Oh, yes and no.
It's difficult to answer.
The regular army knows it can't fight a war by itself, but by the same token,
I guess we'd be known as weekend warriors, which a full-time professional man doesn't connote the highest respect as a group, as an individual might be.
But they were ill-prepared and things.
See, the problem with the military, like a lot of other things, they have these problems.
They create solutions.
Those people are retiring some new people.
See, they had all this replacements.
And I got a list of them all over the Southwest, Louisiana, New Mexico.
Half those people moved to another place, something.
People had been off duty six months.
Gotten married, started in the business, suddenly got recalled to duty without any warning.
They finally had to come out with a pamphlet on it.
Things like that.
Doesn't breathe the greatest of things.
But... Did you like being back on the active duty?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I've never had any aversion to the military.
The hardest job I ever had in my life was being a company commander.
Why was that?
That's a 26-hour day job.
And how big was your company?
200 people.
I don't know.
It was just the hardest job.
I worked hard at being a battalion commander, and I worked hard at being a combat commander, division training commander.
But it seemed to be more, I was directly responsible for every troop around there, 24 hours a day.
Of course, it was wartime.
But...
I had no aversion to going back to active duty.
It was something of an upheaval.
But again, you pay your money and you take the chances.
Do you think the fact that you were on active duty, do you think that that had some impact on your being promoted to brigadier general shortly thereafter?
I don't think there's any question of that.
I think I had the
the sharpest operation down there.
Some of the other combat commanders might question that.
But I do know that we set up our own standing operating procedure for day and night, worked it out ourselves.
I do know that the division standing operating procedure was copied from it.
In fact, they accidentally left some words in it pertaining to us.
We just set up and organized.
I knew what I wanted.
See, they rotated battalions.
And when a battalion came into our thing, we handed them a sheet of paper and said, this will bring you up to date.
Now, we hold Reveille and retreat formation are not spelled out exactly in the regulations.
We said, this is the way we do Reveille, and this is the way we do retreat, and everybody does it the same way.
Any questions?
And they could read all of that and bring them up to where we operate.
How did you first learn that you were going to be promoted to general?
Oh.
That was an interesting and long story.
I was probably the senior qualified colonel at the time.
An interesting story, if you want to hear it.
It took six months.
It took six months until you got the word?
No.
What do you mean it took six months?
It took six months for me to get federally recognized.
Well, when we got back from Polk, Assistant Division Commander Jim Scott, who I served with for a long time, became Assistant Adjutant General Army, which opened up the spot.
So my papers were duly sent in to the National Guard Bureau.
And they came back and said, we're sorry.
But the regulations prescribe that when there's only one Assistant Adjutant General and the Adjutant General is Army, the Assistant Adjutant General has to be Air.
Therefore, the spot wasn't vacant.
Although he was still Adjutant General, he was still technically carried.
He carried his Assistant Division Commander.
So they got a bill through at the last of the legislative session, which provided for an assisted action for General Ayers.
And it was a catch-all bill, and it was on a voice vote.
So they again submitted my papers, and the National Guard Bureau came back and said, we're sorry, but under Texas law, when it's not a vote of record,
the law doesn't come effective until 90 days after the cessation of the legislature.
So I had to wait another 90 days.
In other words, is there a lot of politics in the House?
No.
The old 36th Division, I think, over the years, developed politics in the inns and the houses.
I think the 49th was rather singularly free of politics.
I never did feel like I wasn't politically well-connected, that my promotions had anything to do with just being the right guy at the right time.
Because we were singularly free of politics.
I hear that National Guard is more political than the Army Reserve.
Would you comment on that?
Perhaps.
Because the Army Guard, although federally recognized, the Adjutant General is state-employed.
Within the state of Texas now, in some states, a new governor comes in, he appoints a new Adjutant General.

And in the past year, many years past, when the governor wanted to get rid of an Adjutant General, and the paper would come out about using a government vehicle for personal business or something, we'd finally put enough pressure on him to resign.
But we have more or less had an unwritten deal with governors for several years that they don't do that.
And when Governor Clements came into office, the same acting general was under Dolph Briscoe.
And when Dolph Briscoe came in, whoever was acting general was still the same.
So we've had some excellent continuity.
So I'd say that we're less political than perhaps in other places.
I can't speak for other states.
I'm sure in some instances there's politics involved, particularly the old units, perhaps the later units.
In the 49th, it was almost done.
And with me, my criterion was
Can they do it, or can't they do it?
If they can do it, they stay.
If they can't do it, they go.
I figured I was paid to do a job, and if I didn't do it, they ought to get somebody else.
That simple.
You were made general in 1963, and you had the assistant division CEO.
What did you do as far as that was concerned?
I had more fun as a colonel than a lieutenant colonel ever had as assistant division commander.
Why?
The duties of an assistant division commander, according to regulations, are such duties as may be delegated by the division commander.
In other words, this right up here, in case they ever have a child,
And that's what an assistant military commander is.
I spent most of my time going out to the field, visiting units, checking training, and as much to be seen as to see.
Let them see somebody in the division headquarters and carry them.
General West has to make command inspections of the various commands, but he can't make them all.
During this time, Vietnam was starting to grow.
Did you, were you in any way interested in going over and volunteering for that?
No, not particularly.
I was a member of an organization.
See, we got through at Polk.
Well, before we got through, I left a little early.
I went up to Pentagon for about a little over 30 days.
They had a project in their hip pocket for about 17 months.
They needed to develop a command structure.
For example, Louisiana and Arkansas split a division for a long time.
They needed to have a command headquarters that could take over the troops in those various states.
And so I was detailed, three or four of us were detailed to work on.
And we developed a command structure.

And I had to present to Chief of National Guard, and he argued with me on several points, because I had a small quartermaster section, a small hardening section, and so on and so forth, maybe two officers and three men.
And what the criteria was, not more than 200.
Leave a little fat for the Army to cut out, because they all want to cut out some.
And the chief said, we don't need those quartermaster people and so forth.
We can depend on troops at the post.
And I said, General, we can't depend on troops at the post.
I've been through that.
They don't necessarily know what's going on.
I think we need our own advisors.
He bought it.
And what I was pleased with, it came out reasonably close to what we went after.
What did you think about the work at the Pentagon?
Oh, it was interesting.
The Army is not an efficient organization.
It's not designed to be.
It's designed to fight wars.
They make mistakes.
I used to tell my staff down at Fort Polk,
If you think I'm going to be right 100% of the time, you better rearrange your thinking.
I said, I ought to be right 95% of the time.
That 5% is in minor areas.
And I said, we'll do this.
I'll listen to any suggestion.
You can call me an SOB, and I won't take offense.
But the very instant that I said, that's fine.
Now, this is the way we do it.
you better forget about everything else.
But that was an interesting thing.
I never meant to paint.
What did you think of the quality of all the sir that you were working with that were at the Pentagon?
High quality.
High?
Yes.
Basically, you thought the people that run the regular professional army?
Well, in the Bureau,
the Chief of National Guard for the U.S. National Guard Office.
And it happened to be that the Chief of the Army Branch, General Clayton P. Kerr, used to be a division commander, assistant division commander.
So I didn't go in blind.
In the past,
The local states like Rhode Island, Maryland, places where they just run over the Pentagon, maybe got a little more attention paid to them than some of the southern or western states.
That's been changed now.
The chief of the National Guard Bureau now
He used to be the staff assistant of the Oklahoma National Guard.
I've known him for years.
And he is the first incident last year.
He is the first incident of the Chief National Guard Bureau being promoted to lieutenant general.
And he's a surgeon.
He's fine.
During Vietnam, was
When you were a general in the National Guard, did that seem to have any impact on the Guard in Texas?
No.
I counseled a lot of people, not necessarily the Guard.
The Vietnam War was a particularly war, more so than the Korean War was to me.
I remember during World War II, our entire national effort was directed toward winning the war, our entire national effort.
People went to Vietnam.
I think it felt like that once they left, that everybody went by their own day's business.
There was no national effort behind it.
And besides what I've been able to determine, it was a dirty, nasty war.
And there's always been wars.
During this time, of course, you had the rise of a number of women in the service, and the rise of blacks in the service, or tremendous increase.
Did that have any impact on the National Guard here in Texas?
No.
We had, really we didn't have any women in the National Guard.
We didn't have any probation before.
The Reserves had some probation before, but we didn't have any.
I don't know of any National Guard hospitals and stuff, so we didn't have nurses.
They didn't have any secretaries?
They were all staff assistants.
Blacks, we had some.
We didn't have any large concentration.
They never presented a real problem.
We had, at Fort Polk, we had a lot of village blacks.
And I had one lieutenant that I thought the world
And he was in a predominantly Latin American battalion.
They could carry less.
Unfortunately, he could not cut the mustard, his company commander.
His battalion commander came up and said, I need to make a change in certain company.
I said, that's all right with me.
He said, well, the man I'm putting in is black.
I said, I could carry less.
Can he do the job?
He said, I think he can.
I said, that's all right with me.
And yet he was top rated.
But then I've seen whites the same way.
Why'd you retire?
Because I had a business that was just about to go broke, and I quit in 30 years.
And that business finally ended up costing me a ton of money.
In fact, it broke.
What business were you in?
I went to Plymouth, Minnesota.
And I ended up owning the bank with a ton of money, which it took me several years to pay off.
I don't owe anybody a dime.
What were your thoughts on when you retired?
Were you ready to...
Get out of the garbage?
Not really.
I like it.
I like the people.
I imagine I like the rank.
I'm not happy I found out, being a general, that I had to do one thing to change.
Because if I pulled a cigarette out, it would be about half a dozen people trying to light it.
So I had to get in the habit of pulling my lighter out first.
I'd rather light it on.
But I liked it.
I just didn't understand it.
And I missed it when I got out.
Now, when you were...

In the military, did you think that your promotions were dependent on the people that you knew, or maybe in the right place at the right time, or were they more dependent on your own behavior, your own actions, and your accomplishments?
I would hope they were on my own behavior and my own actions.
I would hope so.
Because when I got promoted to major,
serving under a VMI sick Lieutenant Colonel, regular Army.
And he picked me as his exec.
He was the trial, because he was sick.
I guess I've done a good job as Commander.
Do you think that people get ahead in the professional world the same way that they get ahead in the military world?
Do you think it takes the same type of attributes in the military as other businesses, corporations?
Yes, I would say so.
If an individual expects to succeed in private business and the military, he can't do it by just saying, issuing an order.
He's got to leave.
If you could never run and leave, would you define leadership for him?
Yes, sir, if I can.
Leadership is the ability to
Anticipate, perhaps.
Recognize problems.
Make corrections.
Try to put the right people in the right places.
No one can do it all by themselves.
And you've got to have competent people.
I had so many people down at Fort Polk on my staff.
It wasn't a question if I didn't like the guy firing him and getting him out and getting the other one in.
I did have to make two shifts, which worked out.
Because I had a man that could see a tree, but he couldn't see a forest.
What kind of attributes do you think leaders should have?
What kind of values?
Well, he's got to have pretty high values.
There's been an old saying that
It makes no difference whether it's a company or a battalion or a brigade.
If you've got a tough, tough commander, you need an exec to go around and kind of unruffle the feathers.
If you've got a rather easygoing commander, you need a tough exec to go around and see a thing.
I depend on my people.
I had an excellent executive officer.
I told the battalion commanders that we'll have meetings if we got something to talk about.
We're not going to have daily meetings just to have daily meetings.
I see most of you every day somewhere anyhow.
My exec will have a meeting with your execs every day.
But you understand that what goes through that channel is just the same as me telling you.
And I saved your time.
Because I don't like to have me just hear myself talk.
If there's something to talk about, fine, we'll get together.
Otherwise, get out and do your job.
I suppose so.
I guess everybody aspires to the next higher promotion.
But I guess my consuming desire was to do the best job I knew how.
Whatever I do.
Because I figure that I'm paid to do a good job.
And the people under me are paid to do a good job.
And I feel like if they don't, it's my job to either correct them or get rid of them.
And I had a captain down there.
We were getting ready to come home.
I told him, I said, I suggest that you transfer to another outfit somewhere because you're the last captain I've ever promoted.
What did he do?
He got out.
I sent him on advance to catch me down.
He wrecked his car.
I got to investigating it.
He'd had two previous wrecks.
I can be pretty tough.
I called him in, and I said, you're grounded.
I will not permit you to have a car on this post.
I said, I may not keep you from getting killed, but I may keep somebody else from getting killed.
After three months, he came up, and I said, all right, you go down and bring me a prescription for new glasses from the doctor, and we'll see about it.
But you can't win them all.
Sometimes people have said that there's a military mentality or a military way of thinking.
The Army does it one way, the civilian world does it the other.
Is there a military mentality?
Yes, I think so.
What is it?
Well, you're used to telling a man to do something and telling him how to do it, and he does it that way.
There's been many things, but I still say leadership and civilian occupation leadership in the military is leading, not driving.
Sir William Slim, have you ever heard of him?
He was a British general.
and in the defeat in Malaysia.
And he used to talk about the military as a string of instruments.
And he said, the finest is a battalion.
I can know my people clear down the line.
But he said, even as a general,
and I have regimental commanders.
I go to one and say, Jack, I need that hill by 10 o'clock in the morning.
He says, okay.
I go to the next one and I say, gosh, I'd love to have that hill by 10 o'clock in the morning, but I know you can't do it.
He said, General, I believe I can.
You have to know your people.
You have to try to correct mistakes, just like in the civilian occupation.
Perhaps there's a little bit firmer thing.
I've seen people that swing their weight around.
That doesn't really go in the army.
You've got to wait for a while.
But you have to lead people in this.
You know, frailty, there's no such thing as a perfect soldier.
You have to approach it differently.
I have one last topic I'd like to talk about.
Would you excuse me for a few minutes?
Now I wanted to talk finally about one last thing.
Those changes that we've had at A&M, did you know General Rudder?
Yes, very well.
What did you think of Earl Rudder?
I thought he was a tremendous soldier.
I think he came to A&M as president during the very prime time.
You sure did.
And under his tenure, there are a number of changes, and I'd like to talk about those.
For example, ending the Mandatory Corps.
What was and what is your opinion of that?
It was a sign of the times.
A&M cannot continue to be all military.
and be a large state university at the same time.
What about allowing women?
I think it's one of the greatest things that could have happened.
And I'll tell you what I base that reasoning on, two or three things.
I have talked to many high school principals.
And the general consensus is that
Somewhere along the line, they will counsel with nearly every student that's going on to college.
And almost without exception, they will recommend that go to college.
Their reasoning being that if you're going to work with them, live with them the rest of your life, why separate?
